page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY, GRAINTHORPE
page.content: This showed that most of Grainthorpe, then called Germundstorp, belonged to the{King's manor of Gayton on the {Wold,}and included the adjoining parishes to the west and south. In Grainthorpe, he held 2 caracutes of arable land, with 13 sokemen and 6 villeins with 2 teams of oxen, and 6 salt pans. There were two other Lords of the manor with rights, they were:- {William, the Bishop of Durham}who held 4.5 bovates of land, and 6 villeins with 1 team, 2 oxen and 50 acres of meadow. {William de Percey,}who held 3.5 bovates of arable land, and 3 sokemen with 1 team and 50 acres of meadow.
